trial_identification.studytitle: Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) versus Endotracheal Tube (ETT) on incidence, of perioperative adverse respiratory events, in obese children with recent cold undergoing upper airways surgery.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: the effect of insertion of LMA and ETT in intubating obese children with recent cold on adverse respiratory events(complications).

conditions.healthcondition: Anaesthesiology for obese pediatric patients with recent cold in upper airway surgeries.

interventions.interventions:
(Group I) : LMA group, 32 obese children with recent cold use LMA for intubation in upper airway surgeries.
(Group II): ETT group, 32 obese children with recent cold use ETT for intubation in upper airway surgeries.
interventions.comparator:
use of ETT for intubation of obese children with recent cold in upper airway surgeries.
active control.

primaryOutcome.outcome: compare between LMA and ETT effects on incidence of adverse perioperatively respiratory events, in obese children with uncomplicated recent cold (primary outcome) e.g breath holding, coughing, laryngospasm, bronchospasm, and oxygen desaturation.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: on each stage of anesthesia: at Induction, Insertion of LMA or ETT, Maintenance, Emergence of anesthesia and Postoperative period (until discharge from the post anesthesia care unit)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: early detection and management of complications e.g. aspiration, postoperative nausea and vomiting, bleeding, dysrhythmia (secondary outcome).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: during operations and postoperative period until discharge from hospitals.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
children age 2-8 years with recent uncomplicated cold (without symptomatic wheezing, purulent secretion and fever),
ASA I and II
BMI > 95% of child age and sex. Weight and height were used to measure BMI (weight/height2)
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
children BMI <95% of child age and sex,
symptoms of fever, purulent secretion and wheeze was any of them present,
ASA physical status >II
refusal of parents.

trial_design.sequence: patients were randomized into two equal groups of patients via a table of random numbers using a computer software.
trial_design.designfeatures: Due to the procedures are impossible to be blind to the type of tube being used, all observations are recorded by qualified anesthetists who are not enrolled in the study.
trial_design.statisticalmethods:
Data are presented as mean +/- (SD) for normally distributed data. Baseline characteristics and outcomes across the groups were compared using the Student's t-test for continuous variables and chi-square analysis for nominal data. All analysis has been calculated using SPSS V.16. A P-value of <0.05 was considered to indicate statistical significance.
In deciding sample size we assumed that respiratory complications in obese children with recent cold will be greater than asymptomatic obese children at least by fivefold, if we assumed that complication in asymptomatic obese children will be 5% so we expected incidence of 25% complications in obese children with recent cold, from previous frequencies, based on a previous study on obese children without cold in our hospital a sample size of 29 children in each group will be convenient(a = 0.05 and a power of 0.8 with 95% confidence interval).

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Department of Anesthesia and surgical Intensive care, Faculty of Medicine, Tanta University. EL Geish st. Tanta / Gharbia 31257 Egypt.

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Overweight and obesity in children become a wide problem facing anesthetists' every day. Furthermore, cold is a viral origin infection that commonly occurs in children, there is always debate for years whether to proceed in anesthetizing with general anesthesia or not for children with recent cold because risk of increase incidence of perioperative respiratory adverse events.
this is a prospective randomly unblinded study in 64 obese children (BMI>95% of child age and sex) with recent cold aged 2- 8 years undergoing elective upper airways surgery to compare the incidence of perioperative respiratory adverse events in manipulation of airways either by LMA or ETT (primary outcome), early detection and optimizing the anesthetic management of complications may occur (secondary outcome).
